holtPlane.history:
The Albatros W.4 fulfilled the need for a German Naval fighter to counter the British flying boats in the North and Baltic Seas. Inspired by the earlier Albatros D.I and D.II, the W.4 retained the fuselage and the power plant of the Albatros D.II, but included new wings and tail structures. Twin floats replaced the wheels to equip it for marine operations. Fabric covered the majority of the fighter's wooden frame, except for the engine housing and floats, which were covered with thin metal sheeting.
Design flaws plagued early W.4s. A transparent Cellon panel, mounted in the center upper wing section to improve the pilot's vision, proved to be brittle and prone to tearing off in flight. These were soon replaced by traditional fabric. The W.4 also experienced problems with its engine's two radiators. The radiators, which were uniquely positioned on either side of the fuselage, often boiled over in warm weather. Later versions of the W.4 switched to a single flush mounted radiator located in the center of the upper wing. This arrangement proved to be more satisfactory.
The German Air Force employed the W.4 to counter naval reconnaissance and U-boat hunting missions conducted by British flying boats in the North Sea and Baltic Sea. World War I records are vague about the success or failure of the operations of the W.4. With 128 machines built in all, it can be assumed that they were reasonably successful. At the War's end, various seaplane stations on the Baltic coast still listed 65 of these machines in active service.
holtPlane.deployment: This model represents an aircraft from Windau Air Station, German Air Force, Baltic Coast, February 1917.
